Meet Thomas Ballent and Alice Jahnke Ballent, Class of 1974. The alumni couple first met at Northern Illinois University, both graduating in 1978. Alice went on to a successful career in sales and marketing. Meanwhile, Thomas pursued his master‚Äôs degree and a career in finance. Please join us tonight, 7 p.m. in the York auditorium, for the movie "Angst". This event is presented by Thrive D205 and sponsored by D205 PTA Council.

Angst is an hour-long film that explores anxiety, its causes, effects, and what we can do about it. The movie features interviews with kids and young adults who cope with anxiety. Mental health experts also are interviewed about the causes of anxiety and its sociological effects.

A Q&A session with local mental health professionals will follow the movie. Event is free and open to the public. Families are welcome to attend. The movie is appropriate for grades 6-12.

Parents and guardians of Sandburg students:

At 9:00 this morning, the Sandburg front office was informed by numerous staff members of a gas smell in the building. For the safety of everyone in the building, the fire alarm was pulled and students safely evacuated. The fire department arrived and using gas detection devices, they determined there was no gas leak in the building. They determined it was safe for students to re-enter Sandburg.

We were informed that the smell was caused by Nicor working on gas lines in the area.

Thank you to the Elmhurst Fire Department and the City of Elmhurst for their assistance.

York High School student athletes helped cut the ribbon on a new fitness center last week. The state-of-the-art workout gym grew from vision to reality thanks to a generous $100,000 donation from the York Athletic Boosters. The York Athletic Department partnered with the Elmhurst District 205 School Board to allocate the remaining $20,000 needed for the renovation project.

The new fitness center includes 16-universal, multi-use weight racks and banks of treadmills, elliptical machines, and bikes for cardio workouts. In addition to sports and physical education, any student may use the center to assist with their personal wellness and fitness objectives.

Churchville Middle School was one of 115 schools in Illinois chosen to participate in the 29th annual TECH 2019 student technology showcase held on Tuesday, May 7 at the Illinois State Capitol Building. At the event, students showed the public and members of the Illinois State Senate and House of Representatives how technology is being used in the classroom to increase student engagement and improve achievement.

Taking part in the demonstrations from Churchville Middle School, along with Project Lead the Way teacher Peter Richey, were seventh graders Andrew Gutierrez, Panos Soupos, and Alyssa Caruso.

Congratulations to these students and their teachers for their hard work and dedication!

The students launched a "Ban the Straw" campaign, creating posters, educating fellow classmates about recycling and conservation efforts, began a petition campaign, and contacted district administrators. Their hard work paid off. Plastic straws are now used in Elmhurst D205 lunchrooms only if requested by students.

Congratulations to the York Drama Department and to the cast and crew of "Bright Star" for their production being nominated for best musical in the state of Illinois!

"It is a true honor for a special group of talented, amazing students" says York Theatre Director, Rebecca Marianetti. "To be recognized at this level by the IHSMTA is a huge compliment; the cast, crew, and orchestra of Bright Star are incredible performers and people... the entire creative team is thrilled for York".

On May 6, Students from the cast will perform at the Broadway Playhouse in Chicago, and Erin Lee (Alice Murphy), Bridey Costello (Margo Crawford), Mike Bindeman (Jimmy Ray Dobbs) will perform in front of a panel of professional actors for a chance to go the Jimmy Awards in New York City.
